Spent on infected house [...].
ww_5272aec6907291f8.textOriginal:
[Henry:] His hants are omenous, not the throtes of Rauens,
Spent on infected house [...].

ww_541b77de7b605006.text: [D’Auvergne:] No more viewed than the wallet of their faults.
ww_541b77de7b605006.textOriginal: [D’Auvergne:] No more viewd then the wallet of their faults.

ww_156003024a0ca3a8.text:
[Captain:] And to make this no less than an Ostent;
Another that hath fortun'd since, confirms it:
Your goodly horse Pastrana , which the Archduke,
Gave you at Brussels; in the very hour,
You left your strength, fell mad, and killed himself;
The like chanc'd to the horse the great duke sent you:
And, with both these, the horse the duke of Lorraine,
Sent you at, Vimie made a third presage, [...]
Who like the other pin'd away and died.
[Byron:] [...]The matchless Earl of Essex who some make,
(In their most sure divinings of my death)
A parallel with me in life and fortune,
Had one horse likewise that the very hour,
He sufferd death, (being well the night before)
Died in his pasture.
ww_156003024a0ca3a8.textOriginal:
[Captain:] And to make this no lesse then an Oftent;
Another that hath fortun'd since, confirmes it:
Your goodly horse Pastrana , which the Archduke,
Gaue you at Bruxells; in the very houre,
You left your strength, fel-mad, and kild himselfe;
The like chanc't to the horse the great duke sent you:
And, with both these, the horse the duke of Lorraine,
Sent you at, Vimie made a third presage, [...]
Who like the other pin'd away and died.
[Byron:] [...]The matchlesse Earle of Essex who some make,
(In their most sure diuinings of my death)
A parallell with me in life and fortune,
Had one horse like-wise that the very howre,
He sufferd death, (being well the night before)
Died in his pasture.

ww_149747e5a4fee840.text: [William Smallshank:] [...] Hark, he stirreth not, he moveth not, he waggeth not [...].
ww_149747e5a4fee840.textOriginal: [William Smallshank:] [...] Harke, he stirreth not, he moueth not, he waggeth not [...].

ww_5117f9d49cebe179.text:
[Coriolanus:] [...] The beast
With many heads butts me away.

ww_4efd8b6f8e9994fe.text:
[Captain Pout:] Oh, now I understand you, and you stand over me,
My hurts are not mortal, but you have the better [...].
ww_4efd8b6f8e9994fe.textOriginal:
[Captain Pout:] Oh, now I vnderstand you, and you stand ouer me,
My hurts are not mortal, but you haue the better [...].

ww_3520dc49cd6ec6b7.text: [Captain Pout:] But did that little, old dried Neat's tongue, that Eel-skin get him?
ww_3520dc49cd6ec6b7.textOriginal: [Captain Pout:] But did that little, old dri'de Neats tongue, that Eele-skin get him?

ww_d4b1fde1f4983c59.text:
[Pendant:] Nature herself having made you, fell sick
In love with her own work, and can no more
Make man so lovely, being diseased with love.
ww_d4b1fde1f4983c59.textOriginal:
[Pendant:] Nature her selfe hauing made you, fell sicke
In loue with her owne worke, and can no more
Make man so louelie, being diesasd with loue.

ww_e22040576cc23978.text: For I tell thee Reader, if thou be'st ignorant, a Play is not so idle a thing as thou art, but perfect or imperfect, true or false, a Mirror of men's lives and actions: now, be it perfect or imperfect, true or false, is the Vice or Virtue of the Maker.
ww_e22040576cc23978.textOriginal: For I tell thee Reader, if thou bee'st ignorant, a Play is not so ydle a thing as thou art, but perfect or imperfect, true or false, a Mirrour of mens liues and actions: now, be it perfect or imperfect, true or false, is the Vice or Vertue of the Maker.

ww_5044e24df268782e.text: Likewise most affable Lady, kind and debonair, the second of the first which I saucily salute, pardon I pray you the boldness of a Beggar, who hath been writ down for an Ass in his time, & pleads under forma pauperis in it still, notwithstanding his Constableship and Office.
ww_5044e24df268782e.textOriginal: Likewise most affable Lady, kind and debonaire, the second of the first which I fawcily saute, pardon I pray you the boldness of a Begger, who hath been writ down for an Asse in his time, & pleades under forma pauperis in it still, not-withstanding his Constableship and Office.

ww_fe41f422e3d024f1.text:
[Scudamore:] I am come to speak,
and speak I will freely, and to bring back
Your Letters, and such things you sent; and then,
I'll never see those deceiving eyes again.
[Bellafront:] I am sick of my corruption,
For Godsake do not speak a word more to me.
[Scudamore:] Not speak, yes woman, I will roar aloud,
Call thee the falsest fair that ever breath'd,
Tell thee, that in this marriage, thou hast drown'd
All virtue, left to credit thy weak sex,
which being (as t'were) committed to thy trust,
Thou traitorously hast betrayed it thus. [...]
[Bellafront:] Oh peace, for you speak sharpness to my soul
More tortuous, than hell's plagues to the damn'd […].
[...] Oh thy dear words have knocked at my heart's gates,
and entered: They have plucked the Devil's Vizor [...].
ww_fe41f422e3d024f1.textOriginal:
[Scudmore:] I am come to speake,
and speake I will freely, and to bring backe
Your Letters, and such things you sent; and then,
Ile nere see those deceiuing eyes agen.
[Bellafront:] I am sicke of my corruption,
For Godsake do not speake a word more to me.
[Scudmore:] Not speake, yes woman, I will rore a lowd,
Call thee the falsest faire that euer breath'd,
Tell thee, that in this marriage, thou hast drown'd
All vertue, left to credit thy weake sex,
which being (as t'were) committed to thy trust,
Thou traiterously hast betraid it thus. [...]
[Bellafront:] Oh peace, for you speake sharpnesse to my soule
More tortuious, then hels plagues to the damn'd […].
[...] Oh thy deare words haue knockt at my harts gates,
and entred: They haue pluckt the Diuels Vizard.

ww_6d8b7297e9f60417.text:
[Captain:] I see now how I am cheated. Love him well;
He has redeem'd your honour with his sword,
[Sir John Worldly:] But where is Strange, my son, oh were he here,
He should be married new to make all sure.
[Katherine:] Oh, my Divining Spirit, he's gone to Sea!
ww_6d8b7297e9f60417.textOriginal:
[Captain:] I see now how I am cheated. Loue him well;
He has redeem'd your honour with his sword,
[Sir John Worldly:] But where is Strange, my sonne, oh were he heer,
He should be married new to make all sure.
[Katherine:] Oh, my Diuining Spirit, hee's gone to Sea!

ww_34e29a7ae0642315.text:
[Bellafront:] Oh Basilisk, remove thee from my sight,
Or thy heart's blood shall pay thy rash attempt.
Ho, Who attends us there?
[Scudmore:] Stir not a foot,
And stop your clamorous acclamations,
Or by the bitterness of my fresh wrongs,
I'll send your Ladyship to the Devil quick [...].
ww_34e29a7ae0642315.textOriginal:
[Bellafront:] Oh Basiliske, remooue thee from my sight,
Or thy harts bloud shall pay thy rash attempt.
Ho, Who attends vs there?
[Scudmore:] Stirre not a foote,
And stop your clamorous acclamations,
Or by the bitternesse of my fresh wrongs,
Ile send your Ladiship to the Deuill quicke; [...].

ww_6cd0e827dbdd03f0.text: [Wagtail:] Why, what amends will you make me, can you give me some sum of money to marry me to some Tradesman, as the play says?
ww_6cd0e827dbdd03f0.textOriginal: [Wagtail:] Why, what mends will you make me, can you giue me some sum of money to marrie me to some Tradesman, as the play saies?

ww_34090a8a24eb1ef3.text: [Captain Pout:] God-a-mercy, zounds, methinks I see myself in Moorfields, upon a wooden leg, begging threepence.
ww_34090a8a24eb1ef3.textOriginal: [Captain Pout:] Godamercy, zoones methinkes I see my selfe in Moore-fields, vpon a wodden leg, begging three pence.

ww_dac7069d52e1a40d.text: [Pendant:] They say every woman has a Spring to catch a Woodcock, remember my instructions, and let me see what a Paradise thou canst bring this fool into.
ww_dac7069d52e1a40d.textOriginal: [Pendant:] They say euerie woman has a Sprindge to catch a Wood-Cocke, remember my instructions, and let me see what a Paradice thou canst bring this foole into.

ww_4c282bee2e5f6e72.text:
[Mistress Wagtail:] Oh, thy very name,
Like to a Hatchet cleaves my heart in twain,
When first I saw thee in those little Breeches,
I laugh'd for joy, but when I heard thy speeches,
I smiled downright [...].
ww_4c282bee2e5f6e72.textOriginal:
[Mistress Wagtail:] Oh, thy very name,
Like to a Hatchet cleaues my heart in twaine,
When first I saw thee in those little Breeches,
I laugh'd for ioy, but when I heard thy speeches,
I smil'd downe right [...].

ww_67ecca303d9f5404.text: (A bed drawn forth with Rousard).

ww_ef68002ece256bad.text:
[Fresco:] Good my lord, her rent is great.
The good gentlewoman has no other thing To let her fore-rooms out to others, and
Herself contented to lie backwards.

ww_201ffde06bfd28bd.text:
[First Judge:] His lordship did but paint a rotten post,
 Or cover foulness fairly.

ww_ac4f12b209d8ac62.text:
[D'Amville:] Judgment, judgment!
[Second Judge:] Judgment, my lord, in what?
[D'Amville:] Your judgments must resolve me in a case.

ww_ea7ca14a0547d4ea.text:
[Arviragus:] [...] The ruddock would
With charitable bill - O bill, sore shaming
Those rich-left heirs that let their fathers lie
Without a monument - bring thee all this,
Yea, and furred moss besides, when flowers are none
To winter-ground thy corse.

ww_24b7c604180c4981.text:
[Count Feesimple:] Oh, oh, oh, a pox o' this cold!
 [Welltried:] A cold o' this pox you might say, I am afeared.
ww_24b7c604180c4981.textOriginal:
[Count Feesimple:] Oh, oh, oh, a pox a this cold!
[Welltried:] A cold a this poxe you might say', I am feard.

ww_d2b35cac54c85989.text:
[Belarius:] [...] Stoop, boys. This gate
Instructs you how t'adore the heavens and bows you
To a morning's holy office. The gates of monarchs
Are arched so high that giants may jet through
And keep their impious turbans on, without
Good morrow to the sun.

ww_bf28eebcdda14855.text: [Sebastian:] [...] Let the chambers be matted, the hinges oiled, the curtain rings silenced, and the chamber-maid hold her peace at his own request, that he may sleep the quietlier [...].

ww_fb8bd70948d2fa9d.text:
[Rowland:] Let's remove our places.
Swear it again.
ww_fb8bd70948d2fa9d.textOriginal:
[Rowland:] Let's remove our places.
Sweare it again.

ww_5c5ada0509bc7cf2.text: the close Curtains of the Night

ww_61d56a431d12a73c.text:
[Face:] […] He has made a table,
With Mathematical demonstrations,
Touching the Art of quarrells.
ww_61d56a431d12a73c.textOriginal:
[Face:] […] He has made a table,
With Mathematicall demonstrations,
Touching the Art of quarrells.

ww_83ff37174ffea0f1.text:
[Feesimple:] One and thirty good-morrows to the fairest, wisest, richest Widow, that ever conversation coped withal.
[Widow:] Three score and two unto the wisest Lord,
That ever was train'd in university.
ww_83ff37174ffea0f1.textOriginal:
[Feesimple:] One and thirty good-morrows to the fairest, wisest, richest Widdow that ever conuersation coapt withall.
[Widow:] Three score and two unto the wisest Lord,
That euer was train'd in vniversitie.

ww_a3ee2d72c7c254d0.text:
[D'Amville:] [...] Observ'st thou not the very self same course
Of revolution both in man and beast? [...]
[Borachio:] That revolution is too short methinks.

ww_7c63cd5cdf7c7a11.text:
[King:] O God, that one might read the book of fate
And see the revolution of the times
Make mountains level [...].

ww_9f754e8c7159cd79.text:
[D'Amville:] [...] perhaps I should
Desire no more increase of substance than
Would hold proportion with mine own dimensions.

ww_0fe27c30c773f907.text:
[Brother:] [...] he, and his noble friends
Have such a golden snaffle for the jaws
Of man-devouring Pythagorean Law,
They'll rein her stubborn chaps, e'en to her tail:
And (though she have iron teeth to meaner men)
So master her, that who displeased her most,
She shall lie under like a tired jade [...].
ww_0fe27c30c773f907.textOriginal:
[Brother:] [...] hee, and his noble friends
Haue such a golden snaffle for the jawes
Of man-deouring Pithagorean Law,
Thei'le reyne her stubborn chaps, e'ne to her taile:
And (thogh she haue yron teeth to meaner men)
So master her, that who displeasd her most,
She shall lie vunder like a tired jade [...].

ww_d4b3387304c1798c.text:
[Belforest:] Accompli[sh]ments are more for ornament
Than use.

ww_0bf825c99d9f6999.text:
[D'Amville:] Borachio, didst precisely note this man?
[Borachio:] His own profession would report him pure.

ww_ace6ed61ff9cfcce.text: [Rousard:] Wilt give me a bracelet o' thy hair then?

ww_259ec1ce443166c8.text:
[Castabella:] Do you want hair, sir?
[Rousard:] No, faith, I'll want no hair so lang as I can have it for money.
[Castabella:] What would you do with my hair then?
[Rousard:] Wear it for thy sake, sweetheart.

ww_cde0cd35ca3cde5a.text:
[Bellforest:] [...] But when I
Reply'd with more familiar arguments,
Thinking to make her apprehension bold,
Her modest blush fell to a pale dislike [...].

ww_b99d67d0489cf281.text:
[Posthumus:] [...] I would I were so sure
To win the King as I am bold her honor
Will remain hers.

ww_42f651b9d29cbc92.text: [Castabella:] [...] Time cuts off circumstance; I must be brief.

ww_e0f235266ff44e4a.text:
[Languebeau Snuffe:] [...] Love still desires the presence of his love.
Verily, he is not of the Family of Love.

ww_69e342b2b395a1a2.text: A hall, my masters, give Rotundus room.
ww_69e342b2b395a1a2.textOriginal: A hall, my masters, give Rotundus roome.

ww_d6bc93d96f86f8b7.text:
[Alonso:] [...] Methought the billows spoke and told me of it;
The winds did sing it to me, and the thunder,
That deep and dreadful organ pipe, pronounced
The name of Prosper.

ww_f4b1b7fdd3ff3396.text: [Autolycus:] The King is not at the palace. He is gone aboard a new ship to purge melancholy and air himself, for, if thou beest capable of things serious, thou must know the King is full of grief.

ww_920f02ef5e266e20.text: [Clown:] [...] As I can bear a pack, so I can bear a brain [...].

ww_4b48bbd7199e664c.text: [Staines:] There is a devil has haunted me these three years, in likeness of an usurer, a fellow that in all his life never eat three groat loaves out of his owne purse [...].
ww_4b48bbd7199e664c.textOriginal: [Staines:] There is a diuell has haunted me these three yeares, in likenesse of an Vsurer, a fellow that in all his life neuer eat three groat loaues out of his owne purse [...].

ww_0b7cb22b770995c6.text:
[Florizell:] I take thy hand, this hand,
As soft as dove's down, and as white as it,
Or Ethiopian's tooth, or the fann'd snow that's bolted
By the northern blast twice o'er.

ww_5e5d4a7be7075f00.text:
[Vittoria:] [...] You did name your Duchess.
[Bracciano:] Whose death God pardon.
[Vittoria:] Whose death God revenge [...].
ww_5e5d4a7be7075f00.textOriginal:
[Vittoria:] [...] You did name your Dutchesse.
[Bracciano:] Whose death God pardon.
[Vittoria:] Whose death God reuenge [...].

ww_1c74341ce0767e15.text: [Cornelia:] [...] fetch a looking glass, see if his breath will not stain it; or pull out some feathers from my pillow, and lay them to his lips, will you lose him for a little painstaking?
ww_1c74341ce0767e15.textOriginal: [Cornelia:] [...] fetch a looking glasse, see if his breath will not staine it; or pull out some feathers from my pillow, and lay them to his lippes, will you loose him for a little paines taking?

ww_31579c21b639bbc8.text:
[Queen Katherine:] [...] Take good heed
You charge not in your spleen a noble person
And spoil your nobler soul. I say, take heed -
Yes, heartily beseech you.

ww_893b02700f1a4964.text:
[Norfolk:] Stay, my lord,
And let your reason with your choler question
What 'tis you go about. To climb steep hills
Requires slow pace at first. Anger is like
A full hot horse who, being allowed his way,
Self-mettle tires him.

ww_e50c6f5aec6744d1.text:
[Wolsey:] Nay then, farewell!
I have touched the highest point of all my greatness,
And from that full meridian of my glory
I haste now to my setting. I shall fall
Like a bright exhalation in the evening
And no man see me more.

ww_e80a6737fc66062b.text: [Ferdinand:] [...] What I have done, I have done: I'll confess nothing.
ww_e80a6737fc66062b.textOriginal: [Ferdinand:] [...] What I haue don, I haue don: I'll confesse nothing.

ww_efde7d3c79c6abf0.text:
[Cardinal:] Satisfy thy longing,
The only way to make thee keep my counsel,
Is not to tell thee.
ww_efde7d3c79c6abf0.textOriginal:
[Cardinal:] Satisfie thy longing,
The onely way to make thee keepe my councell,
Is not to tell thee.

ww_405d5c17bc1473cd.text: [Malateste:] Thou wretched thing of blood [...].
ww_405d5c17bc1473cd.textOriginal: [Malateste:] Thou wretched thing of blood [...].

ww_88889f33e24d6049.text: Excellent Queen! what do my words, but wrong thy worth? what do I but guild gold? what, but she the Sun with a candle in attempting to praise thee, whose honor doth fly over the whole world upon the two wings of magnanimity, and justice, whose perfection shall much gimme the Lustre of all other, that shall be of thy Sex.
ww_88889f33e24d6049.textOriginal: Exzellent Queene! what doe my words, but wrong thy worth? what doe I but guild gold? what, but she the Sunne with a candle in attempting to praise thee, whose honor doth fly over the whole world upon the two winges of magnanimity, and justice, whose perfectione shall much gimme the Lustre of all other, that shall be of thy Sexe.

ww_87d2e4eaedc58dba.text:
[Duchess:] [...] Yet stay, heaven gates are not so highly arch'd
As Princes palaces, they that enter there
Must go upon their knees [...].
ww_87d2e4eaedc58dba.textOriginal:
[Duchess:] [...] Yet stay, heauen gates are not so highly arch'd
As Princes pallaces, they that enter there
Must go vpon their knees [...].

ww_296cf5497405a93a.text:
[Ferdinand:] Get thee into some unknown part o'th' world
That I may never see thee.
ww_296cf5497405a93a.textOriginal:
[Ferdinand:] Get thee into some vnknowne part o'th' world
That I may neuer see thee.

ww_5230b2287c6dada6.text:
[Prologue:] We pray our play may be so, for I am sure
It has a noble breeder and a pure,
A learnèd, and a poet never went
More famous yet 'twixt Po and silver Trent.
Chaucer, of all admired, the story gives;
 There, constant to eternity, it lives.

ww_8b207258f9035916.text:
My tongue in fire dragons' spleen I steepe,
That acts, with accents, cruelty may found [...]

ww_95e7aafc05da02c6.text:
My working head (my counsel's consistory)
Debates how I might range, the princess living.

ww_80ee910e072a66b9.text:
The devilish fury in my breast intends,
In spite of danger and all opposite bars;
To cut this knot the mystic fates contain,
And set my life and kingdom on this main.

ww_0af3189ea0a5007e.text: [Almachildes:] […] The whoreson old hellcat would have given me the brain of a cat once, in my handkerchief [...].
ww_0af3189ea0a5007e.textOriginal: [Almachildes:] […] The whorson old Helcat, would haue given me the Brayne of a Catt once [...].

ww_9a189b4e58de4a45.text: [Second:] [...] tell me in what language I shall roar a lecture to you, or I'll read to you the mathematical science of roaring.
ww_9a189b4e58de4a45.textOriginal: [Second:] [...] or ile read to you the Mathematicall science of Roaring.

ww_c9cea4739d297b14.text:
[Charlois:] And look that you that have been eagle-eyed
In other men's affairs, prove not a mole
In what concerns yourself.
ww_c9cea4739d297b14.textOriginal:
[Charlois:] And looke that you that haue beene Eagle-eyd
In other mens affaires, proue not a Mole
In what concernes your selfe.

ww_048555f2dc8b011e.text:
[Rutilio:] There is an hour in each man's life appointed
To make his happiness if then he seize it [...].
ww_048555f2dc8b011e.textOriginal:
[Rutilio:] There is an hour in each mans life appointed
To make his happinesse if then he seize it [...].

ww_5c88e7ec94fbbc89.text:
[Diocletian:] I believe
Your tongues are the true Trumpets of your hearts,
And in it I most happy Queen of fate,
Imperious Fortune mix some light disaster
With my so many joys to season 'em,
And give them sweeter relish [...].
ww_5c88e7ec94fbbc89.textOriginal:
[Dioclesian:] I beleeue
Your tongues are the true Trumpets of your hearts,
And in it I most happy Queene of fate,
Imperious Fortune mixe some light disaster
With my so many ioyes to season em,
And giue them sweeter rellish [...].

ww_c08d294bf16ad0dc.text:
[Vortiger:] [...] Methinks the murder of Constantius
Speaks to me in the voice of't, and the wrongs
Of our late queen, slipp'd both into one organ [...].
ww_c08d294bf16ad0dc.textOriginal:
[Vortiger:] [...] Methinks the murther of Constantius
Speaks to me in the voice of't, and the wrongs
Of our late queen, slipp'd both into one Organ.

ww_144ff64e9aea8ae0.text: Like an ass, he wears out his time for provender [...].

ww_c1321e89ed368946.text:
[Diocles:] [...] I dedicate to Virtue; and to keep
my faith untainted, farewell Pride and Pomp,
and circumstance of glorious Majesty,
farewell for ever.
ww_c1321e89ed368946.textOriginal:
[Diocles:] [...] I dedicate to Vertue; and to keep
my faith untainted, farewell Pride and Pomp,
and circumstance of glorious Majestie,
farewell for ever.

ww_4413dc320607af33.text:
[Diocles:] No, I will not be pluck'd out by the ears
out of this glorious castle; uncompell'd
I will surrender rather: Let it suffice,
I have touch'd the height of human happinesse,
and here I fix Nil ultra.
ww_4413dc320607af33.textOriginal:
[Diocles:] No, I will not be pluck'd out by the ears
out of this glorious castle; uncompell'd
I will surrender rather: Let it suffice,
I have touch'd the height of humane happinesse,
and here I fix Nil ultra.

ww_d62cb0b0761c8c89.text:
[Florence:] Your own eyes shall be witness how: nay, nay, pray rise,
I know your heart is up, tho your knees down.
ww_d62cb0b0761c8c89.textOriginal:
[Florence:] Your owne eyes shall be witnesse how: nay, nay, pray rise,
I know your heart is up, tho your knees downe.

ww_52a9db9a073098b0.text:
[Cleora:] I restore
This kiss, so help me goodness!
which I borrow'd
When I last saw you.
ww_52a9db9a073098b0.textOriginal:
[Cleora:] I restore 
This kisse, (so help me goodnesse,) which I borrow'd, 
When I last saw you.

ww_2d815be36cdc9217.text: [Bellisant:] I will expose myself to all assaults see masks & hear bewitching sonnets, change discourse with one that for experience could teach Ovid to write a better way his art of love feed high; and take & give free entertainment [...].
ww_2d815be36cdc9217.textOriginal: [Bellisant:] I will expose myself to all assaults see maskes & heare bewitchinge sonnetts, change discourse with one that for experinence Could teach ouid to write a better waie his art of loue feede high; and take & giue free entertainement [...].

ww_5ffb4d12af1bec9e.text:
[Clarinda:] [...] (since 'tis said
& truly Jupiter & Venus smile
at Lovers' perjuries) [...].
ww_5ffb4d12af1bec9e.textOriginal:
[Clarinda:] [...] (since tis said
& trulie Iupiter & venus smile
at Lovers periuries) [...].

ww_62eb98faef9b939f.text: [Chamont:] No, that were too much mercy, live to be wretched, live to be the talk of the conduit and the bakehouse, I will have thee pictured as thou art now, & thy whole story sung to some villanous tune in a lewd ballad and make thee so notorious to the world that boys in the streets shall hoot at thee [...].
ww_62eb98faef9b939f.textOriginal: [Chamont:] noe that weare too much mercy live to bee wretched, live to bee the [take] talke of the Conduit & the bake howse, I will haue thee picterd as thou art now, & thie whole story sunge to some villanous tune in a lewd ballet & make thee so notorious to the world that boyes in the streetes shall hoote at the [...].

ww_1d91fb9a0409efbb.text:
[Philippo:] To throw the pawn
Of my afflicted honour, and on that
I openly affirm your absent Lady
Chastity's well-knit abstract, snow in the fall,
Purely rein'd by the bleak Northern blast,
Not freer from a soil, the thoughts of Infants;
But little nearer heaven.
ww_1d91fb9a0409efbb.textOriginal:
[Philippo:] To throw the pawn
Of my afflicted honour, and on that
I openly affirm your absent Lady
Chastitie's well-knit abstract, snow in the fall,
Purely rein'd by the bleak Northern blast,
Not freer from a soyl, the thoughts of Infants;
But little neerer heaven.

ww_65a416060e1927b3.text:
[Orator:] [...] the Apparel and the Jewels that she wore,
more worth than all her Tribe [...].
ww_65a416060e1927b3.textOriginal:
[Orator:] [...] the Aparrel and the Jewels that she wore,
more worth then all her Tribe [...].

ww_eab4edc2de6a05bb.text:
[Conrade:] No Masks! No Epithalamion now!
Call for a bonesetter, for Time hath sprain'd
His feet, and goes awry.
ww_eab4edc2de6a05bb.textOriginal:
[Conrade:] No Maskes! No Epithelamion now!
Call for a Bonesetter, for Time hath sprain'd
His feete, and goes awry.

ww_a076a5d170c6033a.text:
[Chamont:] Nay be not mov'd sir,
Let his passion work, and like a hot rein'd horse
'Twill quickly tire itself.
ww_a076a5d170c6033a.textOriginal:
[Chamont:] Nay be not mov'd sir,
Let his passion worke, and like a hot rein'd horse
'Twill quickly tire it selfe.

ww_83b03fd6ac19fab7.text:
[Rhodolinda:] The King! How sportful he is grown? how full
Of amorous game and dalliance?
[Hermegild:] I spy Valdaura there: but is that the King?
ww_83b03fd6ac19fab7.textOriginal:
[Rhodolinda:] The King! How sportfull he is growne? how full
Of amarous game and dalliance?
[Hermegild:] I spie Valdaura there: but is that the King?

ww_28e4e1a85fad60f3.text:
[Aretinus:] Are you on the stage,
You talk so boldly?
[Paris:] The whole world being one
This place is not exempted.
ww_28e4e1a85fad60f3.textOriginal:
[Aretinus:] Are you on the stage,
You talk so boldly?
[Paris:] The whole world being one
This place is not exempted.

ww_36506e021585fe78.text:
[Hermegild:] It shows but silly art in industry,
To seek what you would not find.
[Rhodolinda:] I prithee grow particular! Dost think
They purpose ought ith' dark? […]
[Hermegild:] The King was never given to compliment,
You know. As for Valdaura -
[Rhodolinda:] What of her?
[Hermegild:] I think that she is chaste, but - […]
I wish the King had not deserved to be
Deprived of your soft embraces [...].
ww_36506e021585fe78.textOriginal:
[Hermegild:] It shewes but silly art in industry,
To seeke what you would not finde.
[Rhodolinda:] I prethee grow particular! Dost thinke
They purpose ought ith' darke? […]
[Hermegild:] The King was neuer giuen to complement,
You know. As for Valdaura -
[Rhodolinda:] What of her?
[Hermegild:] I thinke that she is chaste, but - […]
I wish the King had not deseru'd to be
Depriu'd of your soft imbraces [...].

ww_4eac470a88d48de2.text:
[Hermegild:] Mark how close they meet: what variety
They use in lust: now she hath melted quite his lips
With her hot breath, she hangs upon his ear.
ww_4eac470a88d48de2.textOriginal:
[Hermegild:] Marke how close they meete: what variety
They vse in lust: now she hath melted quite his lips
With her hot breath, she hangs vpon his eare.

ww_0a66c1449b36a2cd.text:
[Paradine:] Let me enjoy thy hand! that moist Diamond
That so attracts my soul!
ww_0a66c1449b36a2cd.textOriginal:
[Paradine:] Let me enioy thy hand! that moyst Adamant
That so attracts my soule!

ww_2fd6667c31283abe.text:
[Gentleman:] [...] the fair dames,
Beauties, that lights the court, and makes it thew
Like a fair heaven in a frosty night:
And 'mongst these mine, not poorest [...].
ww_2fd6667c31283abe.textOriginal:
[Gentleman:] [...] the faire dames,
Beauties, that lights the Court, and makes it thew
Like a faire heaven, in a frosty night:
And mangst these mine, not poorest [...].

ww_4bb280a983fdfd66.text:
[Paradine:] Then glorious war, and all proud circumstance,
That gives a soldier noise, for evermore farewell - [...].
ww_4bb280a983fdfd66.textOriginal:
[Paradine:] Then glorious war, and all proud circumstance,
That giues a souldier noyse, for euermore farewell - [...].

ww_a162d198fb34066e.text: [Paradine:] Let's to't like Monkeys, or the reeking Goat.
ww_a162d198fb34066e.textOriginal: [Paradine:] Let's to't like Monkeys, or the recking Goat.

ww_b5ecd45a5760c296.text:
[Rhodolinda:] My cross fate
Like the Raven, croaks a funeral note [...].
ww_b5ecd45a5760c296.textOriginal:
[Rhodolinda:] My crosse fate
Like the Rauen, croaks a funerall note [...].

ww_a71cef0647735267.text: [Grimold:] I'll bribe your Lordship with a Ginny Toothpick!

ww_104a7ab2ccd818a6.text:
[Cunymond:] And whilst you are in physic (Captain)
You fare like Oberon [...].
ww_104a7ab2ccd818a6.textOriginal:
[Cunymond:] And whilst you are in physick (Captaine)
You fare like Oberon [...].

ww_06ce35c84941a538.text: [Cunymond:] I wear it as a Jewel in my ear.
ww_06ce35c84941a538.textOriginal: [Cunymond:] I weare it as a Iewell in my eare.

ww_f0932e315d765937.text:
[Rhodolinda:] How! lie with him? I'll sooner choose a Mansion
In a sepulcher: There commit incest
With the raw remnant of my father's bones:
Sooner embrace an aerie Incubus:
Mingle Limbs with some ulcerous Cripple,
Able to infect a Hospital.
ww_f0932e315d765937.textOriginal:
[Rhodolinda:] How! lye with him? Ile sooner choose a Mansion
In a sepulcher: There commit incest
With the raw remnant of my fathers bones:
Sooner imbrace an ayrie Incubus:
Mingle Limmes with some vlcerous Cripple,
Able to infect an Hospitall.

ww_ce9042043fb0b670.text: [Frollo:] He sits like a witch, sailing in a sieve.
ww_ce9042043fb0b670.textOriginal: [Frollo:] He sits like a Witch, sayling in a siue.

ww_7b4b7bd72533b2ab.text:
[Paradine:] Brutus, noble Brutus! the pride
Of arts and war: so temperate, his soul
was more harmonious than the spheres.
ww_7b4b7bd72533b2ab.textOriginal:
[Paradine:] Brutus, noble Brutus! the pride
Of Arts and Warre: so temperate, his soule
VVas more harmonious then the Spheares.

ww_88ce1c70a002bcbc.text: [Paradine:] <span class="quote">There died the noblest Trophy of our war!/span>
ww_88ce1c70a002bcbc.textOriginal: [Paradine:] There dy'd the noblest Trophey of our war!

ww_daf751aa3d5e5922.text:
[Rhodolinda:] Think on thy country, Paradine! Is there
In story no mention of some great soul,
That did his country prize above his own
Mortality, and died to gain his Nation Freedom?
[Hermegild:] The Noble Brutus for his country's health,
Made Cesar bleed; Cassius was heroic too [...].
ww_daf751aa3d5e5922.textOriginal:
[Rhodolinda:] Thinke on thy Country, Paradine! Is there
In Story no mention of some great Soule,
That did his Country prize aboue his owne
Mortalitie, and dy'd to gaine his Nation Freedome?
[Hermegild:] The Noble Brutus for his Countreys health,
Made Cesar bleed; Cassius was heroique too [...].

ww_457dde68b449cab2.text:
[Paradine:] Why did
The mighty Cesar fall, by thy cold wrath?
ww_457dde68b449cab2.textOriginal:
[Paradine:] Why did
The mighty Cesar fall, by thy cold wrath?

ww_5b7a9d8a19d5a3e7.text:
[Foreste:] Her soul is gone!
Hah? whether is it gone? O vast suspense!
Madness succeeds inquiry. Fools of Nature!
What Ancestor (that died long since) hath brought
Us news of his abode! or told us how
They use him in the other world? O this
Wild mystery so much concerneth Man:
That we would willingly dismiss suspense
With eyesight not with consequence.
ww_5b7a9d8a19d5a3e7.textOriginal:
[Foreste:] Her Soule is gone!
Hah? whether is it gone? O vast suspence!
Madnesse succeeds inquirie. Fooles of Nature!
What Ancestor (that dyde long since) hath brought
Vs newes of his abode! or told vs how
They vse him in the other world? O this
Wilde mysterie so much concerneth Man:
That we would willingly dismisse suspence
With Eiesight not with consequence.

ww_4b45029fc9cbe140.text:
[Duke:] Did not high-providence,
Treble the assurance of my safety:
By Guards invisible, when I was first
Predestinate to this supreme function?
And dare thou tempt the strength of heaven?
ww_4b45029fc9cbe140.textOriginal:
[Duke:] Did not high-prouidence,
Treble the assurance of my safety:
By Guards inuisible, when I was first
Predestinate to this supreame function?
And darst thou tempt the strength of Heauen?

ww_ad36992e1795126a.text:
[Cosimo:] And is himself secure; happily drunk,
Or riding in the stews; you may take some
Advantage on his soul too. Lose no time.
[Lothario:] That's my intent.
For it were dull humanity to aim
No farther then his life. I'll pursue him
Even to Hell.
ww_ad36992e1795126a.textOriginal:
[Cosimo:] And is himselfe secure; happely drunke,
Or riding in the stewes; you may take some
Aduantage on his soule too. Loose no time.
[Lothario:] That's my intent.
For it were dull humanitie to aime
No farther then his life. I'le pursue him
Euen to Hell.

ww_989e05b21959e001.text:
[Foreste:] You are the Duke's creature! who dotes by art,
Who in his love, and kindness, method keeps.
ww_989e05b21959e001.textOriginal:
[Foreste:] You are the Dukes Creature! who doates by Art,
Who in his loue, and kindnesse, Method keepes.

ww_cf6381216e8ee608.text:
[Castruchio:] unless I imitate the crab,
And find my way (as he does his) backwards.
ww_cf6381216e8ee608.textOriginal:
[Castruchio:] Vnlesse I imitate the Crab,
And find my way (as he doth his) backwards.

ww_d6c9a567da83e907.text:
[Lidia:] O the difference of natures! Giovanni,
A prince in expectation, when he lived here,
Stole courtesy from heaven, and would not, to
The meanest servant in my father's house,
Have kept such distance.

ww_fc4681b98c39196d.text:
[Corsa:] O my Brother! whilst I am yet human,
Let me feel some interest in your blood.
What fault of mine deserves impediments
In my last journey? If my Lord were here
He would have seen me vs'd (?) with mercy.
[Foreste:] Sweet Soule! these, are but mistakes of weakness.
[Corsa:] Will not my Lord be merciful; to me,
And to my memory (riseth up).
[Foreste:] Sit still. I bring no negative reply.
Thy worth shall shine in such a character:
That being dead; he needs must woe thy Ghost.
ww_fc4681b98c39196d.textOriginal:
[Corsa:] O my Brother! whilst I am yet humane,
Let me feele some interest in your blood.
What fault of mine deserues impediments
In my last iourney? If my Lord were heere
He would haue seene me vs'd with mercy.
[Foreste:] Sweete Soule! these, are but mistakes of weakenesse.
[Corsa:] Will not my Lord be mercifull; to me,
And to my memory (riseth up).
[Foreste:] Sit still. I bring no negatiue reply.
Thy worth shall shine in such a Character:
That being dead; he needs must wooe thy Ghost.

ww_173ddd1ce872fad3.text:
[Borachio:] I'll not be his ass,
That served for blows, and provender.
ww_173ddd1ce872fad3.textOriginal:
[Borachio:] I'le not be his Asse,
That seru'd for blowes, and Prouander.

ww_fcd3ab9b3356d28b.text:
[Anne:] If you be Bateman;
T'were best you travelled d from my father's ground
Lest he indite you?
ww_fcd3ab9b3356d28b.textOriginal:
[Anne:] If you be Bateman;
T'were best you traveld from my fathers ground
Least he indite you?

ww_3c068ca905d4ca72.text:
[Sciolto:] They've watched
My hardy violence so tame [...].
ww_3c068ca905d4ca72.textOriginal:
[Sciolto:] They'ue watch'd
My hardy violence so tame [...].

ww_401c225de0764fd2.text:
[Camiola:] [...] Will it ever be
That to deserve too much is dangerous,
And virtue, when too eminent, a crime?
ww_401c225de0764fd2.textOriginal:
[Camiola:] [...] will it ever be
That to deserve too much is dangerous,
And vertue, when too eminent a crime?

ww_60cf8c7115891e92.text:
[Goodlack:] You are not mad, sir? You say you love her.
[Spencer:] Never question that.
[Goodlack:] Then put her to't, win opportunity, she['s] the best bawd. If (as you say) she loves you, she can deny you nothing.
ww_60cf8c7115891e92.textOriginal:
[Goodlack:] You are not mad sir? You say you love her.
[Spencer:] Never question that.
[Goodlack:] Then put her to't, win Oportunity,
Shee the best bawd: If (as you say) she loves you,
She can deny you nothing.

ww_3969009383bfa54e.text:
[Berecinthius:] [...] mother of the gods what is he [...]
at his best but a Patrician of Rome,
His name's Titus flaminius, and speak mine
Berecinthius Archflamen to Cybele it makes as great a sound.
ww_3969009383bfa54e.textOriginal:
[Berecinthius:] [...] mother of the gods what is hee [...]
at his best but a Patritian of Rome,
His name Titus flaminivs, and speake mine
Berecinthivs Archflamen to Cybele it makes as greate a sownde.

ww_1937b66745dbbdc4.text:
[Antiochus:] [...] to assure it with all pomp
and circumstance of glory [...].
ww_1937b66745dbbdc4.textOriginal:
[Antiochus:] [...] to assure it with all pompe
and circumstance of glorie [...].

ww_a7d2be92263b9b55.text:
[Paulinus:] Yet take heed,
Take heed Lord Philanax , that for private spleen
 Or any false conceived grudge against me,
[...] you do not that
My royal Master must in justice punish [...].
ww_a7d2be92263b9b55.textOriginal:
[Paulinus:] Yet take heede,
Take heede Lord Philanax , that for priuate spleene
 Or any false conceiued grudge against mee,
[...] you doe not that
My royall Master must in iustice punish [...].

ww_acfc8be01bda1743.text: [Theodosius:] [...] Me thinks I find Paulinus on her lips [...].
ww_acfc8be01bda1743.textOriginal: [Theodosius:] [...] Mee thanks I finde Paulinus on her lips [...].

ww_0d4ad8ab460757df.text:
[Simo:] That I should have so ravishing a face,
And never know it! - Miser that I was!
I will go home and buy a looking glasse,
To be acquainted with my parts hereafter.

ww_7bd0c46cbe0aa3f3.text: And if but an ordinary artist should with a watchful eye diligently and narrowly observe the ordinary proceeding of such an Aesculapius, he should observe him often, [...] to soothe up his patient [...] when not withstanding this grim Sergeant seizes on the prisoner without bail or main price.
ww_7bd0c46cbe0aa3f3.textOriginal: And if but an ordinary artist should with a watchfull eye diligently and narrowly observe the ordinary proceeding of such an Aesculapius, he should observe him often, [...] to sooth up his patient [...] when not withstanding this grim Sergeant ceisez on the prisoner without baile or main price.

ww_fa2c092898ef46f2.text:
[Aphelia:] [...] But what I saw was real; heard'st thou nothing?
[Isabel:] I heard discourse of people in your Chamber
Some half an hour since, but they went forth,
And to my seeming full of discontent,
But know not who they were.
[Aphelia:] Oh it is too true;
I'll to my Father's, my Prophetic soul
Sits like a Mine of lead within me; come
Help me to mourn my Girl, for this sad sight
Besits a funeral, not a Bridal night.
ww_fa2c092898ef46f2.textOriginal:
[Aphelia:] [...] But what I saw was reall; heard'st thou nothing?
[Isabel:] I heard discourse of people in your Chamber
Some half an hour since, but they went forth,
And to my seeming full of discontent,
But know not who they were.
[Aphelia:] Oh it is too true;
I'l to my Fathers, my Prophetique soul
Sits like a Mine of lead within me; come
Help me to mourn my Girl, for this sad sight
Besits a funerall, not a Bridall night.

ww_d743d2f1ed21b17d.text:
[Cassandra:] [...] my prophetic soul
Knew this before.
ww_d743d2f1ed21b17d.textOriginal:
[Cassandra:] [...] my prophetick soule
Knew this before.

ww_4c4454da00b0563b.text: In Election God bestowes on us his love, in Calling he grants the blessing of his word, in Justifying he communicates to us the sweetness of his spirit; in Glorifying he doth wholly give us himself. We see far with our body's eye, sense: further with the mind's eye, Reason; furthest with the soul's eye, Faith. The Rational eye doth not so far exceed the sensual, as the spiritual exceeds the rational. Calling illuminates the mind with knowledge; Sanctifying seals up the heart with spiritual comfort: salvation crowns all, even the soul with immortal bliss.
ww_4c4454da00b0563b.textOriginal: In Election God bestowes on us his love, in Calling he grants the blessing of his word, in Justifying he communicates to us the sweetness of his spirit; in Glorifying he doth wholly give us himself. We see far with our bodies eye, sense: further with the minds eye, Reason; furthest with the soules eye, Faith. The Rationall eye doth not so far exceed the sensuall, as the spiritual exceeds the rationall. Calling illuminates the mind with knowledge; Sanctifying seals up the heart with spirituall comfort: salvation crowns all, even the soule with immortall blisse.

ww_477e4e6e9e7bb004.text:
[Adorio:] Heaven be pleas'd to qualify this excess of happiness
With some disaster, or I shall expire
With a surfeit of Felicity [...].
ww_477e4e6e9e7bb004.textOriginal:
[Adorio:] Heaven be pleas'd to qualifie this excess of happiness
With some disaster, or I shall expire
With a surfeit of Felicity [...].

ww_045c010f4380102f.text: This goodly frame of the world [...].

ww_74431c216556ab3f.text:
[Alvaro:] Could change my corslet, and my iron vests
Of rugged war, to move in gentle pace,
Unto the tuneful whispers of thy lute [...].
ww_74431c216556ab3f.textOriginal:
[Alvaro:] Could change my corslet, and my iron vests
Of rugged war, to move in gentle pace,
Vnto the tunefull whispers of thy Lute [...].

ww_4ea87fd00be3b4a2.text:
[Jacintha:] Falstaff I will believe thee,
There is no faith in villanous man.
ww_4ea87fd00be3b4a2.textOriginal:
[Jacintha:] Falstasse I will beleeve thee,
There is noe faith in vilanous man.

ww_433754d2880dabda.text:
[Theander:] Like sullen roses that would wither on
The bough, e're throughly blown, e're gather'd for
The Still; so lose all memory that they were ever sweet.
ww_433754d2880dabda.textOriginal:
[Theander:] Like sullen Roses that would wither on
The Bough, e're throughly blowne, e're gather'd for
The Still; so lose all memorie that they were ever sweet.

ww_aa1de87b830b7b4c.text:
[Bornewell:] [...] And Ladies thither bound by a Subpoena
Of Venus, and small Cupid's high displeasure,
Tis but the family of love translated
Into more costly sin [...].
ww_aa1de87b830b7b4c.textOriginal:
[Bornewell:] [...] And Ladies thither bound by a Subpena
Of Venus , and small Cupids high displeasure,
Tis but the family of love translated
Into more costly sinne [...].

ww_f0f9bc1eff7630f0.text: Inhabited so long, nor any impure thought aim at the mudding of this purest Fountain. Whether her prophetic Soul foresaw the snares of the ungodly, and so shunn'd them, they say not [...].
ww_f0f9bc1eff7630f0.textOriginal: Inhabited so long, nor any impure thought ayme at the mudding of this purest Fountaine. Whether her prophetick Soule foresaw the snares of the ungodly, and so shun'd them, they say not [...].

ww_559abdfea9a8a60b.text: [Messalina:] Swallow me earth, gape gape and swallow […].

ww_e679ef8164b2da43.text: They would speak Dagger points, as Joab discoursed with Amasa in the fifth rib.
ww_e679ef8164b2da43.textOriginal: They would speake Dagger points, as Joab discoursed with Amasa in the fift [sic] rib.

ww_399bca065aa9ac45.text:
[Orsini:] [...] This night the French, and Genovese intend
To seize our empty fleet, that rides i'th harbour;
Those men I have endeared, -
Mount, mount my soul, let no fear weigh thee down,
He stakes his life that thus casts at a Crown.
ww_399bca065aa9ac45.textOriginal:
[Ursini:] [...] 'Tis well, if this slander can but pull on murder upon him, or any of my servants, from Valenzo's hand, his head shall answer for't; I am his judge. (My power over the King makes mee so:)
And he shall find mee cruell; then the fort is mine,
In which his souldiers are in garrison;
å This night the French, and Geno wayes intend
To ceize our emptie fleete, that rides i'th harbour;
Those men I have indear'd, -
Mount, mount my soule, let no feare weigh thee downe,
He stakes his life that thus casts at a Crowne.

ww_fccdaa4ef6ef4635.text:
[Oramont:] What strange divinity is that, which guards
These Kings (the lawful terrors of mankind)
Keeps them as safe from punishment, when they
Oppress the tame and good, as it secures
Them from the treachery of the fierce, and bad.
ww_fccdaa4ef6ef4635.textOriginal:
[Oramont:] What strange divinity is that, which guards
These Kings (the lawful terrors of mankind)
Keeps them as safe from punishment, when they
Oppress the tame and good, as it secures
Them from the treachery of the fierce, and bad.

ww_de197f739a0bc601.text:
[Amadore:] Are there no terrors near
The Grave? No angry Spirits, whose
Imployment is to hurry, and transmit the Soul
From flame to flame, from wind to wind (Poor
Vex'd and weary stranger?)

ww_1ce2753819f11a82.text: [Eumena (kneels):] For 'tis the last request I ere shall make.

ww_7266a241dead155c.text:
[Samorat:] The Prince of Darkness is a gentleman,
Mahu, Mohu is his name.
ww_7266a241dead155c.textOriginal:
[Samorat:] The Prince of darknesse is a Gentleman,
Mahu, Mohu is his name.

ww_addbc84983e1f3c5.text:
[Pellegrin:] Is't ev'n so? Why then,
Farewell the plumed troops, and the big wars,
Which made ambition virtue.
ww_addbc84983e1f3c5.textOriginal:
[Pellegrin:] I'st er'n so? Why then,
Farewell the plumed Troops, and the big Wars,
Which made ambition vertue.

ww_2ea9cb1f4b1433a1.text:
[Peridor:] I've found it out,
He does intend to fetch this stranger back,
And give him Reginella,
Or else - No, no, it must be that
His anger, and the search declare it;
The secret of the prison-house shall out I swear.
ww_2ea9cb1f4b1433a1.textOriginal:
[Peridor:] I've found it out,
He doe's intend to fetch this stranger backe,
And give him Reginella,
Or else - No, no, it must be that
His anger, and the search declare it;
The secret of the prison-house shall out I sweare.

ww_07c5f416234320e0.text:
[Simanthes:] With the pardon
Of your most sacred Majesty, 'tis fit then
Your great commands forbid the Prince's voyage:
Boldness enforces youth to hard achievements
Before their time, makes them run forth like lapwings
From their nest, part of the shell yet sticking
Unto their downy heads.

ww_dcd4d83639eddb4d.text: [Leopoldo:] I must finde this Maid though thousand Difficulties oppose; 'tis the very Figure in my Sisters Dream. - O Bellamira, thy prophetick soul has foreseen all our Troubles both of minde and body.

ww_02d0e7b91b9cf1c8.text: [Amadeo:] Sir, by Manlius we sent a message to great Otho; Clorinda 's Prophetick soul proposed it, our desires were few and short, being the sence of those minds which never yet were false; we only ask to be used like friends to the Romans; that we once dared to be enemies ought not to prejudice us, but rather shew us worthy the honour of a peace, which, with honour, is all we ask, and then command us.

ww_f6d062dbb67b0fd8.text:
[Delirus:] [...] We
Are married to another world Artesia, let them
Injoy the happiness in this (if there be any in't)
That are wedded to it, whom we with pity, not
With envy must behold. And 'tis no little joy, amid'st
Our sea of troubles, to see thee thus prepar'd for
Death; which we'l imbrace as greedily, as
Shipwrackt travellers do the long'd for shoare: [...].

ww_c45c344b27eac392.text: New Broom sweeps clean: Frosty age and youth suit not well together.

ww_18ebc98c1b84077e.text:
[Cleopatra:] And if to see a Brother justly kill'd
 To Nature I as well as Reason yield.

ww_4e22b3a5df92d646.text:
[Bibber:] Well, in short, I was drunk; damnably drunk with Ale; great Hogen Mogen bloody Ale: I was porterly drunk; and that I hate of all things in Nature.
[Burr (rising):] And of all things in Nature I love it best.
[Bibber:] Art thou there I'faith; and why, old Boy?
[Burr:] Because when I am porterly drunk, I can carry my self.

ww_c09deb8c7bcabc34.text:
[Maid:] Yes, I have heard stories, how some men
Have in such lonely places been affrighted
With dreadful shapes and noises. (Macduff hollows.)
[Lady Macduff:] But hark, my Lord sure hollows;
'Tis he; answer him quickly.
[Servant:] Illo, ho, ho, ho. (Enter Macduff.)
[Lady Macduff:] Now I begin to see him: are you a foot, My Lord?

ww_72e93a8b981a0764.text:
[King Richard:] You say too much: I see, you'l rather prove
The Subject of my Justice, then my Love.
Th'Invader Richmond is your lov'd Gallant,
Whose Treason does not your allowance want.
Prepare for marriage, or a Funeral;
To be my Wife, or not to be at all.
Madam, you shall be crown'd; Chuse and be wise;
Either for Empire, or for Sacrifice.

ww_fdc0d3fc51293da6.text: [Theodese:] Fruits ripen soonest that are near the Sun.

ww_c9d5f208006acbda.text:
[Doctor:] Sir, he must feel if he can discover of what side her heart lies: I'l keep him in discourse the mean while.
[Gernette:] Must he feel her heart, Doctor? still it runs in my mind, this Apothecary will do me a mischief: nay, be not angry.
[Doctor:] Nay, I forgive you, I see an old man's twice a child, pray you walk into the next room, I must talk in private with you.
[Gernette:] I should sound, if I should leave my child with the Apothecary.

ww_973d29d77f9913b4.text:
[Cloris:] How now Lucia; is my Father up?
[Lucia:] No, not a Mouse stirs yet; I have kept a true
Watch all this night, for I was cruelly afraid
Lest we should have been surpriz'd -
Is the Prince gone? but why do I ask,
That may read it in your sad looks?

ww_cadd1976f92633f1.text:
[Alcippus:] You merit death for this base injury.
But you're my Prince, and that I own you so,
Is all remains in me of sence or justice;
The rest is rage, which if thou get'st not hence
Will eat up that small morsell too of reason,
And leave me nothing to preserve thy life with.

ww_101389c2316e6172.text:
[Don Gerardo:] [...] Death, like your Childrens Bug-bears,
Is fear'd by all, yet has no other Being
Then what weak fancy gives it; 'tis a Line,
But yet imaginary, drawn betwixt
Time and that dreadful thing Eternity;
I, that's the thing, 'tis fear'd; for now I find it:
Eternity which puzzles all the World,
To name the Inhabitants that People it:
Eternity, whose undiscover'd Countrey
We Fools divide, before we come to see it;
Making one part contain all happiness,
The other misery, then unseen fight for't.

ww_78d4a149b4f0704a.text:
[Young Jorden:] By that means we shall get quit of him.
[Trickmore:] The posture our affairs are in at present, do not much seem to require his absence, therefore I have contriv'd a defeat, and will keep him yet in play. I have set another Spring, which if it catch the Woodcock, 'twill hold him fast. Look here comes forth our Knight in Petty-coats: muffle your self up in your Cloak, and be gon.
[Young Jorden:] A stately dame on my word.

ww_fb296e7e36e15945.text:
[Isabella:] You had best marry him, Nan, and let some Gentleman have good luck to Horse-flesh by you.
[Nan:] But, Madam, a rich Citizen is a brave thing.
[Lady Haughty:] I hate to see a Husband walk the length of his Shop as a Fox, or a Civet-Cat does the length of his Chain, backward and forward, backward and forward.
[Isabella:] And then his House is so dark, as if he were mad, and put there to recover his Wits.
[Lady Haughty:] And a Garden scarce big enough to lye at length, and be buried in.

ww_efc63a761653d40c.text: [Gervas the Grange-man:] Love, why thou art a lusty Wench, and that will provoke thee, Love is nothing but being lusty, the rest is twittle twattle: they say Love is a Boy, by the Mass I think Love is a Girl by that: it may be you young Wenches think Love is a Boy, you love Boys too well to the disgrace of Beards. Ah consider, you know not what a man is, I would fain have you know me, there is pith, there is pith in a man, and that thou shalt find to thy cost, if thou'lt but marry me, by the Mass.

ww_d0dbf91b4c3f7afd.text:
lex. Read these; for from Antipater they came,
That dares protest Olympia is to blame.
He much against her government complains,
Sayes he is wrong'd, whilest she wou'd take the paines
There is the like from Aristotle too,
That writes what false Antipater has said, is true;
But I'le let Aristotle know one tear
From my dear Mothers Eyes can wash her clear,
[175] And drown a thousand thoughts that are severe.
What ail the Preists ! They tremble, and look pale,
And all in fears forsake the sacred Rail. -
Give me the Bowl, and the Gods drink prepare.

ww_f9595960fd03a2f1.text:
The Wolves have prey'd, and look the gentle Day,
Before the Wheels of Phoebus, all about
Dapples the drowsy East with spots of gray.

ww_8fb4b31cdcd9e9ee.text:
[Lady Fancy:] Maundy, have you commanded all the Servants to Bed?
[Maundy:] Yes Madam, not a Mouse shall stir, and I have made ready the Chamber next the Garden for your Ladyship.

ww_6fc561c14e2adcc2.text:
Phor:] Who, my Lord, this man?
[Oedipus:] This Man, this old, this venerable Man:
Speak, did'st thou ever meet him there?
[Phor:] Where, sacred Sir.
[Oedipus:] Near Mount Cithæron; answer to the purpose:
'Tis a King speaks; and Royal minutes are
Of much more worth than thousand Vulgar years [...].

ww_8b2181fe7b83009a.text:
[Marc Antony:] O ye Gods!
Have I then liv'd to be excus'd to Caesar?
[Dollabella:] As to your equal.
[Marc Antony:] Well, he's but my equal:
While I wear this, he never shall be more.
[Dollabella:] I bring conditions from him.

ww_73a7a99f5d6a1e5a.text:
[Tiresias:] So short a time as I have yet to live
Exceeds thy pointed hour; Remember Lajus:
No more; if e're we meet again, 'twill be
In Mutual darkness; we shall feel before us
To reach each others hand; Remember Lajus. (Exit Tiresias: Priests follow.)
[Oedipus (alone):] Remember Lajus! that's the burden still:
Murther, and Incest! but to hear 'em nam'd
My Soul starts in me: the good Sentinel
Stands to her Weapons; takes the first Alarm
To Guard me from such Crimes.

ww_cf9ba3081b2e79eb.text:
[Sunamire:] O! we are poorly caught in our own snare.
The poison, we prepar'd for them, the slave
Has given to us.
[Arbanes:] Ha! poison'd! - yes 'tis here:
I feel the Traitor working to my heart.
But I have yet a sword, that shall prevent
The turns of fate, and we will fall reveng'd.

ww_3a1c73e712659a06.text:
[King:] Secure in that, I'le trust thee; Shall I trust thee?
For Conquerors have Charms, and Women Frailty:
Farewel, Thou may'st behold me King agen,
My Soul's not yet depos'd, why then farewel,
I'le say't as comfortably as I can:
But O curs'd Guise, for pressing on my time,
 And cutting off Ten thousand more Adieus.

ww_9521f8cd84752b81.text:
[Madman:] I'll pull down Honor from the pale-fac'd Moon,
 And break the Wheels of the all-circling Sun.

ww_027a0597bb60f00c.text: [Bays.:] Must. Mr. Eugenius? What do you give the must to a man of my Character and Gravity? Were Reasons as cheap as Blackberries, I'de not give you one I gad upon compulsion.

ww_66af294686e29e7a.text:
[King:] To morrow Guise is made Lieutenant-General,
Why then to morrow I no more am King;
'Tis time to push my slack'nd vengeance home,
To be a King, or not to be at all;
The Vow that manacled my Rage is loos'd,
Even Heaven is wearied with repeated Crimes,
Till lightning flashes round to guard the Throne,
And the curb'd Thunder grumbles to be gone.

ww_f4ba9fee1d9fe544.text:
[Dresswell:] Pox on 'em all: prithee turn out those petty Tyrants of thy Heart, and fit it for a Monarch, Love, dear Widling, of which thou never knewst the pleasure yet, or not above a day.
[Wilding:] Not knew the pleasure! Death, the very Essence, the first draughts of Love: Ah, how pleasant is to drink when a man's adry! The rest is all but dully sipping on. [Dresswell:] And yet this Diana, for thither thou art going, thou hast been constant to this three or four years.

ww_c521cb3c27d377b0.text:
[Queen M.:] (stopping the King) What mean you, Sir,
You tremble and look pale, for Heavens sake think,
'Tis your own Life you venture, if you kill him.
[King:] Had I ten thousand Lives, I'le venture all.
Give me way, Madam.

ww_970d9266fb4d263b.text:
[Alphonso:] 'Tis enough you know him.
[Rogero:] Know him! ah God help thee, and the quantity of thy Brains, by thy impertinent Catechism.
[Alphonso:] Why then old Truepenny the Duke is now most violently in labour.
[Rogero:] In labour! Alas, I am in pain for thee.

ww_d0124a28b5675fde.text: Was not that lofty, now? Then there's the Lion, Wall, and Moonshine, three Heroic Parts; I play'd 'em all at School. I roar'd out the Lion so terribly, that the Company call'd out to me to roar again.
ww_d0124a28b5675fde.textOriginal: Was not that lofty, now? Then there's the Lion, Wall, and Moonshine, three Heroick Parts; I play'd 'em all at School. I roar'd out the Lion so terribly, that the Company call'd out to me to roar again.

ww_4efc0cd3efc69d2a.text:
[Philander:] Oh my Heart!
This is a Salve worse than the main Disease.
Tell me thy Thoughts, for I will know the least
That dwells within thee, or will rip thy Heart
To know it: I will see thy Thoughts as plain
As I do now thy Face.
[Endymion:] Why, so you do.
She is (for ought I know) by all the Gods,
As chaste as Ice; but were she foul as Hell,
And I did know it thus; the Breath of Kings,
The Points of Swords, Tortures, nor Bulls of Brass,
Should draw it from me.

ww_58faf6a3572fd33a.text: [Sir Cautious:] Ha, ha, ha - why this is the strangest thing - to see an old Fellow, a Magistrate of the City, the first Night he's marryed forsake his Bride and Bed, and come arm'd Cap-a-pee, like Gargantua, to disturb another old Fellow and banter him with a Tale of a Tub; and all to be-cuckold him here - in plain English what's your Business?

ww_0709ceb513573de3.text:
Yet nevertheless, my father did me not mislike:
But age so simple is, and easy to subdue:
As childhood weak, thats void of wit and reason quite:
They think there's nought, you flatter fainde, but all is true:
Once olde and twice a child, tis said with you,
Which I affirm by proof, that was defined:
In age my father had a childish mind.
ww_0709ceb513573de3.textOriginal:
Yet nathelesse, my father did me not mislike:
But age so simple is, and easye to subdue:
As childhode weake, thats voide of wit and reason quite:
They thincke thers nought, you flater fainde, but all is true:
Once olde and twice a childe, tis said with you,
Which I affirme by proofe, that was definde:
In age my father had a childishe minde.

ww_7dbb5d33002621e6.text:
Father and mother was welcome then,
And so were they all in good faith:
The husband sat there like a man,
The wife did serve them all that day.
The good man commanded what he would have,
The wife was quick at hand,
What now thought the mother, this arrant knave,
Is master as I understand.
ww_7dbb5d33002621e6.textOriginal:
Father and mother was welcome then,
And so were they all in good fay:
The husband sate there like a man,
The wyfe did serue them all that day.
The good man commaunded what he would haue,
The wyfe was quick at hand,
What now thought the mother, this arrant knaue,
Is mayster as I vnderstand.

ww_731d0242dfeed90f.text: Disguise is the only element lacking in a blot-cluster appearing in Edmund Ironside. The linenumbers which follow are those of the Malone Society edition: blot (749), heaven(s) (785, 789), night (793), moon (786), eye (783), frost (744) for winter, sun (786), forsaken (755) and fickle (770) for (in)constancy, monarchs (777) for sovereign. It will be noted that the main body of this cluster is somewhat separated from -the keyword;

ww_9d3baa89b50ec5a2.text: [...] There are things called whips in store.

ww_6c6fe3c0ce5a6724.text:
[King:] The hell of life that hangs upon the Crown,
The daily cares, the nightly dreams,
The wretched crewe, the treason of the foe,
And horror of my bloody practise past,
Strikes such a terror to my wounded conscience,
That sleep I, wake I, or whatsoever I do,
Methinks their ghosts comes gaping for revenge,
Whom I have slain in reaching for a Crown.
Clarence complains, and crieth for revenge.
My Nephew's bloods, Revenge, revenge, doth cry.
The headless Peers comes preasing for revenge.
And every one cries, let the tyrant die.
The Sun by day shines hotly for revenge.
The Moon by night eclipseth for revenge.
The stars are turnd to Comets for revenge.
The Planets change their courses for revenge.
The birds sing not, but sorrow for revenge.
The silly lambs sits bleating for revenge.
The screeking Raven sits croaking for revenge.
Whole heads of beasts comes bellowing for revenge.
And all, yea all the world I think,
Cries for revenge, and nothing but revenge.
But to conclude, I have deserved revenge.
ww_6c6fe3c0ce5a6724.textOriginal:
[King:] The hell of life that hangs vpon the Crowne,
The daily cares, the nightly dreames,
The wretched crewes, the treason of the foe,
And horror of my bloodie practise past,
Strikes such a terror to my wounded conscience,
That sleepe I, wake I, or whatsoeuer I do,
Meethinkes their ghoasts comes gaping for reuenge,
Whom I haue slaine in reaching for a Crowne.
Clarence complaines, and crieth for reuenge.
My Nephues bloods, Reuenge, reuenge, doth crie.
The headlesse Peeres comes preasing for reuenge.
And euery one cries, let the tyrant die.
The Sunne by day shines hotely for reuenge.
The Moone by night eclipseth for reuenge.
The stars are turnd to Comets for reuenge.
The Planets chaunge their coursies for reuenge.
The birds sing not, but sorrow for reuenge.
The silly lambes sits bleating for reuenge.
The screeking Rauen sits croking for reuenge.
Whole heads of beasts comes bellowing for reuenge.
And all, yea all the world I thinke,
Cries for reuenge, and nothing but reuenge.
But to conclude, I haue deserued reuenge.

ww_208c4f9727c1df62.text:
[Richard:] I do mistake my person all this while!
Upon my life, she finds, although I cannot,
Myself to be a marv'lous proper man.
I'll be at charges for a looking glass
And entertain a score or two of tailors
To study fashions to adorn my body.
Since I am crept in favor with myself,
I will maintain it with some little cost.
But first I'll turn yon fellow in his grave
And then return lamenting to my love.
Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass,
That I may see my shadow as I pass.

[King Richard:] Now is this golden crown ike a deep well
That owes two buckets, filling one another,
The emptier ever dancing in the air,
The other down, unseen, and full of water.
That bucket down and full of tears am I,
Drinking my griefs, whilst you mount up on high.

Brief as the lightning in the collied night,
That, in a spleen, unfolds both heaven and Earth,
And, ere a man hath power to say "Behold!"
The jaws of darkness do devour it up.
So quick bright things come to confusion.

ww_4bc1729e33323c0f.text:
About the walls of the chamber in curious imagery were the seven sages of Greece, set forth with their several virtues, eloquently discovered in Arabic verses: The bed appointed for the prince to rest himself, was of black Ebony enchased which Rubies, Diamonds and Carbuncles, made inform of an arch, on which by degrees mans state from infancy to his old age was plainly depictured, and on the testere of the bed the whole contents of the same most sagely desciphered in these verses.

Humanae Miseriae discursus.
O whereof boasteth man, or by what reason
Is filthy clay so much ambitious?
Whose thoughts are vain, and alter every season
Whose deeds are damned, base, and vitious,
Who in his cradle by his childish crying
Presages his mishaps and sorrows denying.
An infant first from nurses tit he sucketh
With nutriment corruption of his nature:
And from the root of endless error plucketh
That taste of sin that waits on every creature,
And as his sinews firm his sin increaseth,
And but till death his sorrow never ceaseth.
In riper years when youthly courage raineth,
A winters blast of fortunes lowring changes,
A flattering hope wherein no trust remaineth,
A fleeting love his forward joy estranges:
Achieve he wealth, with wasteful wo he bought it,
Let substance fail, he grieves, and yet he sought it.
In staled years when as he seeks the gleaning
Of those his times in studious Arts bestowed,
In sum, he oft misconstrueth wise-mens meanings,
Soiling the spring from whence his science flowed,
In all he gains by perfect judgement gained,
A hate of life that hath so long remained.
From height of throne to abject wretchedness,
From wondrous skill to servile ignorance:
From court to cart, from rich to recklessness,
The joys of life have no continuance:
The king, the caitiff wretch, the lay, the learned.
Their crowns, woes, wants, & wits with grief have earned.
The Judgement seat hath brawls, honour is hated,
The soldiers life is daily thrall to danger,
The merchants bag by tempests is abated,
His stock still serves for prey to every stranger,
The scholar with his knowledge learns repent,
Thus each estate in life hath discontent.
And in these trades and choice estates of living,
Youth steals on manly state, and it on age,
And age with weakned limbs, and mind misgiving,
With trembling tongue repenteth youthly rage,
And ere he full hath learned his life to govern,
He dies, and dying doth to dust return.
His greatest good is, to report the trouble
Which he in prime of youth hath overpassed.
How for his grains of good he reapt but stubble,
How lost by love, by follies hew disgraced,
Which whilst he counts, his son perhaps attendeth,
And yet his days in self like follies endeth.
Thus mortal life on sodaine vanisheth.
All like a dream, or as the shadow fleeteth,
When sun his beam from substance banisheth,
Or like the snow at once that dries and sleeteth.
Or as the rainebow which by her condition
Lives by the Sun's reflect and opposition.
Thus life in name is but a death in being,
A burden to the soul by earth entangled:
Then put thou off that vail that lets thy seeing,
O wretched man with many torments mangled,
Since neither child, nor youth, nor staid, nor aged,
The storms of wretched life may be asswaged.
And with the Egyptian midst thy delicates
Present the shape of death in every member,
To make thee know the name of all estates:
And midst thy pomp thy nying grave remember,
Which if thou dost, thy pride shall be repressed
Since none before he dies is perfect blessed.
ww_4bc1729e33323c0f.textOriginal:
About the walles of the chamber in curious imagerie were the seuen sages of Greece, set forth with their seueral vertues, eloquently discouered in Arabicke verses: The bed appointed for the prince to rest himselfe, was of blacke Ebonie enchased which Rubies, Diamons and Carbunls, made inform of an arch, on which by degrees mans state from infancie to his olde age was plainly depictured, and on the testerne of the bed the whole contents of the same most sagelie desciphered in these verses.

Humanae Miseriae discursus.
O whereof boasteth man, or by what reason
Is filthy clay so much ambitious?
Whose thoughts are vaine, and alter euery season▪
Whose deedes are damned, base, and vitious,
Who in his cradle by his childish crying
Presageth his mishaps and sorrowes nying.
An infant first from nurces teat he sucketh
With nutriment corruption of his nature:
And from the roote of endlesse errour plucketh
That taste of sinne that waites on euery creature,
And as his sinewes firme his sinne increaseth,
And but till death his sorrow neuer ceaseth.
In riper yeares when youthly courage raineth,
A winters blast of fortunes lowring changes,
A flattering hope wherein no trust remaineth,
A fleeting loue his forward ioy estranges:
Atchiue he wealth, with wastefull wo he bought it,
Let substance faile, he grieues, and yet he sought it.
In staied yeares when as he seekes the gleaning
Of those his times in studious Artes bestowed,
In summe, he oft misconstrueth wise-mens meanings,
Soiling the spring from whence his science flowed,
In all he gaines by perfect iudgement gained,
A hate of life that hath so long remained.
From height of throne to abiect wretchednesse,
From woonderous skill to seruile ignorance:
From court to cart, from rich to rechlesnesse,
The ioyes of life haue no continuance:
The king, the caitife wretch, the lay, the learned.
Their crowns, woes, wants, & wits with griefe haue erned.
The Iudgement seate hath brawles, honour is hated,
The souldiers life is dayly thrall to danger,
The marchants bag by tempests is abated,
His stocke still serues for prey to euery stranger,
The scholler with his knowledge learnes repent,
Thus each estate in life hath discontent.
And in these trades and choice estates of liuing,
Youth steales on manly state, and it on age,
And age with weakned limmes, and mind misgiuing,
With trembling tongue repenteth youthly rage,
And ere he full hath learnd his life to gouerne,
He dies, and dying doth to dust returne.
His greatest good is, to report the trouble
Which he in prime of youth hath ouerpassed.
How for his graines of good he reapt but stubble,
How lost by loue, by follies hew disgraced,
Which whilst he counts, his sonne perhaps attendeth,
And yet his dayes in selfe like follies endeth.
Thus mortall life on sodaine vanisheth.
All like a dreame, or as the shadow fleeteth,
When sunne his beame from substance banisheth,
Or like the snow at once that dries and sleeteth.
Or as the rainebow which by her condition
Liues by the Sunnes reflect and opposition.
Thus life in name is but a death in beeing,
A burthen to the soule by earth intangled:
Then put thou off that vaile that lets thy seeing,
O wretched man with many torments mangled,
Since neither childe, nor youth, nor staid, nor aged,
The stormes of wretched life may be asswaged.
And with the Egyptian midst thy delicates
Present the shape of death in euery member,
To make thee know the name of all estates:
And midst thy pompe thy nying graue remember,
Which if thou dost, thy pride shall be repressed▪
Since none before he dies is perfect blessed.

ww_183113b64fcaa623.text:

Is dearly bought;

ww_e18a59e7b7a79f87.text:
[Berowne:] Never durst poet touch a pen to write
Until his ink were tempered with love’s sighs.
O, then his lines would ravish savage ears
And plant in tyrants mild humility.
From women’s eyes this doctrine I derive.
They sparkle still the right Promethean fire.
They are the books, the arts, the academes
That show, contain, and nourish all the world.

ww_9f21b308c922ccff.text: [Holofernes:] You find not the apostrophus, and so miss the accent. Let me supervise the canzonet. [He takes the paper.] Here are only numbers ratified, but, for the elegancy, facility, and golden cadence of poesy - caret. Ovidius Naso was the man. And why indeed "Naso," but for smelling out the odoriferous flowers of fancy, the jerks of invention? Imitari is nothing: so doth the hound his master, the ape his keeper, the tired horse his rider. - But damosella virgin, was this directed to you?

ww_5a1acb78f90e1108.text: [Falstaff:] Nay, that's past praying for. I have peppered two of them. Two I am sure I have paid, two rogues in buckram suits. I tell thee what, Hal, if I tell thee a lie, spit in my face, call me horse. Thou knowest my old ward. Here I lay, and thus I bore my point. <span class="quote">Four rogues in buckram let drive at me.</span<

Are at this hour asleep! O sleep, O gentle sleep,
Nature's soft nurse, how have I frighted thee,
That thou no more wilt weigh my eyelids down
And steep my senses in forgetfulness?

 [Pistol:] Die men like dogs! Give crowns like pins! Have we not Hiren here?

ww_f054a9138f536c2c.text:

When I was dry with rage and extreme toil,
Breathless and faint, leaning upon my sword,
Came there a certain lord, neat and trimly dressed,
Fresh as a bridegroom, and his chin new reaped
Showed like a stubble land at harvest home.

ww_297b24b6e36ffa83.text:
[Poins:] Good morrow, sweet Hal. - What says Monsieur Remorse? What says Sir John Sack-and-Sugar? Jack, how agrees the devil and thee about thy soul that thou soldest him on Good Friday last for a cup of Madeira and a cold capon’s leg?
[Prince:] Sir John stands to his word. The devil shall have his bargain, for he was never yet a breaker of proverbs. He will give the devil his due.
 [Poins:] Then art thou damned for keeping thy word with the devil.

ww_8dcbf7f31493abc9.text:
But oh! the absolute Castilio [...]
Tut, he is famous for his revelling,
For fine set speeches, and for sonetting;
He scorns the viol and the scraping stick,
And yet's but Broker of another's wit.
Certes if all things were well known and view'd
He doth but champ that which another chew'd.
Come come Castilion, skim thy posset curd,
 Show thy queer substance, worthless, most absurd.
ww_8dcbf7f31493abc9.textOriginal:
Tut, he is famous for his reueling,
For fine sette speeches, and for sonetting;
He scornes the violl and the scraping sticke,
And yet's but Broker of anothers wit. Certes if all things were well knowne and view'd
He doth but champe that which another chew'd.
Come come Castilion, skim thy posset curd,
 Show thy queere substance, worthlesse, most obsurd.

ww_365dec37e5c90901.text:
Shall broking pandars suck Nobility?
Soiling fair stems with foul impurity?
Nay, shall a trencher slave extenuate,
Some Lucrece's rape? and straight magnificate
Lewd Jovian lust? Whilst my satiric vein
Shall muzzled be, not daring out to strain
His tearing paw? No gloomy Juvenal,
 Though to thy fortunes I disastrous fall.
ww_365dec37e5c90901.textOriginal:
Shall broking pandars sucke Nobilitie?
Soyling fayre stems with foule impuritie?
Nay, shall a trencher slaue extenuate,
Some Lucrece rape? and straight magnificate
Lewd Iouian lust? Whilst my satyrick vaine
Shall muzled be, not daring out to straine
His tearing paw? No gloomie Iuvenall,
Though to thy fortunes I disastrous fall.

ww_38b790db39d91938.text:
Luscus, what's played to day? faith now I know
I set thy lips abroach, from whence doth flow
Naught but pure Juliet and Romeo.
Say, who acts best? Drusus or Roscio,
Now I have him, that ne'er of ought did speak
But when of plays or Players he did treat.
H'ath made a common-place book out of plays,
And speaks in print: […] speaks he not movingly,
From out some new pathetic Tragedy?
He writes, he rails, he jests, he courts what not,
And all from out his huge long scraped stock
Of well-penn'd plays.
ww_38b790db39d91938.textOriginal:
Luscus, what's playd to day? faith now I know
I set thy lips abroach, from whence doth flow
Naught but pure Iuliat and Romio.
Say, who acts best? Drusus or Roscio,
Now I have him, that nere of ought did speake
But when of playes or Plaiers he did treate.
H'ath made a common-place booke out of plaies,
And speakes in print: […] speakes he not movingly,
From out some new pathetique Tragedy?
He writes, he railes, he iests, he courts what not,
And all from out his huge long scraped stock
Of well-penn'd playes.

[Panulpho Felice:] Dead?
[Antonio:] Dead.
[Alberto:] Dead?
[Antonio:] Why now the womb of mischief is deliver'd,
Of the prodigious issue of the night.
[Panulpho Felice:] Ha, ha, ha.
[Antonio:] My father dead, my love attained of lust:
Thats a large lye, as vast as spacious hell:
Poor guiltless Lady.
ww_fc1b7ad7c6b9f394.textOriginal:
[Balurdo:] Courage, courage sweet Ladie, tis sir Gefferey Balurdo bids you courage. Truly I am as nimble as an Elephant about a Ladie.
[Panulpho Felice:] Dead?
[Antonio:] Dead.
[Alberto:] Dead?
[Antonio:] Why now the womb of mischiefe is deliver'd,
Of the prodigious issue of the night.

[Antonio:] My father dead, my loue attaint of lust:
Thats a large lye, as vast as spatious hell:
Poore guiltlesse Ladie.

ww_80a9aba994cf1672.text:
[Laertes:] [...] And keep you in the rear of your affection,
Out of the shot and danger of desire.
The chariest maid is prodigal enough
If she unmask her beauty to the moon.
Virtue itself 'scapes not calumnious strokes.
The canker galls the infants of the spring
Too oft before their buttons be disclosed,
And, in the morn and liquid dew of youth,
Contagious blastments are most imminent.
Be wary, then; best safety lies in fear.

[Hieronimo:] [...] And yonder pale faced He-cat there, the Moon,
Doth give consent to that is done in darkness,
And all those Stars that gaze upon her face,
Are agates on her sleeve pins on her train,
And those that should be powerful and divine,
Do sleep in darkness when they most should shine.
ww_be49c1bf4bf69520.textOriginal:
[Hieronimo:] [...] And yonder pale faced Hee-cat there, the Moone,
Doth giue consent to that is done in darkensse,
And all those Starres that gaze vpon her face,
Are aggots on her sleeue pins on her traine,
And those that should be powerfull and diuine,
Doe sleepe in darkenes when they most should shine.

ww_f618684dbcba63bf.text:
[Guy:] Brother, if I knew where to go to war,
I would not stay in London one hour longer.
[Charles:] An hour! By heaven I would not stay a minute.
[Eustache:] A minute, not a moment. Would you put a moment
Into a thousand parts, the thousandth part,
Would not I linger, might I go to war.
ww_f618684dbcba63bf.textOriginal:
[Guy:] Brother, if I knew where to go to warre,

[Eustache:] A minute, not a moment. Would you put a moment
Into a thousand parts, the thousandth part,
Would not I linger, might I go to warre.

Of the wide world dreaming on things to come,
Can yet the lease of my true love control,
Supposed as forfeit to a confined doom.

ww_92b07fd9f90e45e7.text:
[Isabella:] [...] Why all the souls that were were forfeit once,
And He that might the vantage best have took
Found out the remedy. How would you be
If He which is the top of judgment should
But judge you as you are? O, think on that,
And mercy then will breathe within your lips
Like man new-made.

ww_a5b068f2e2050cb2.text: [Pompey:] [...] Then is there here one Master Caper, at the suit of Master Three-pile the mercer, for some four suits of peach-colored satin, which now peaches him a beggar. Then have we here young Dizzy and young Master Deep-vow, and Master Copper-spur and Master Starve-lackey the rapier-and-dagger man, and young Drop-heir that killed lusty Pudding, and Master Forth-light the tilter, and brave Master Shoe-tie the great traveler, and wild Half-can that stabbed Pots, and I think forty more, all great doers in our trade, and are now "for the Lord’s sake."

[Celso:] I faith my Lord, that beast with many heads
The staggering multitude recoils apace,
Though thorow great mens envy, most men's malice,
Their much intemperate heat hath banished you.
Yet now they find envy and malice near,
Produce faint reformation.
ww_427ae1c236d8f36d.textOriginal:
[Celso:] I faith my Lord, that beast with many heads
The staggering multitude recoiles apace,
Though thorow great mens enuie, most mens malice,
Their much intemperate heate hath banisht you.
Yet now they finde enuie and mallice neere,
Produce faint reformation.

ww_d0f56f015fcc6b2d.text: [Malevole:] [...] I'll give you a simile; Did you e'er see a well with two buckets, whilst one comes up full to be emptied, another goes down empty to be filled? Such is the state of all humanity [...]. why look you, I may be the son of some Duke; for, believe me, ïntemperate lascivious bastardy makes Nobility doubtful: I have a lusty, daring heart, Mendoza.
ww_d0f56f015fcc6b2d.textOriginal: [Malevole:] [...] Ile give you a symilie; Did you ere see a Well with 2 buckets, whilst one comes up full to be emptied, another goes downe emptie to be filled? Such is the state of all humanitie [...]. why looke you, I may be the sonne of some Duke; for, beeleve me, ïntemperate lascivious bastardie makes Nobilitie doubtfull: I have a lusty, daring hart, Mendoza.

ww_e1266fc565370a23.text:
As a black veil upon the wings of morn,
Brings forth a day as clear as Venus' face,
Or, a fair Jewel by an Ethiop worn,
Enricheth much the eye, which it doth grace,
Such is her beauty, if it well be told,
Plac'st in a Jetty Chariot set with gold.
ww_e1266fc565370a23.textOriginal:
As a black vaile vpon the wings of morne,
Brings forth a day as cleere as Venus face,
Or, a faire Iewell by an Ethiope worne,
Inricheth much the eye, which it doth grace,
Such is her beautie, if it well be told,
Plac'st in a Iettie Chariot set with gold.
